awd_titl_txt: Organizational Constructions of a New Right
awd_abstract_narration:
New claims to health-based rights have become a center of mobilization and dispute. This research examines new rights imposed within  health-care settings. It will make intellectual contributions to the study of (1) organizational constructions of rights and (2) the relationship between health and rights. It engages significant questions about interconnections between law, health, and rights and investigates a new site at a moment of legal innovation. The hypotheses incorporate insights from research into organizational dispute processing. The research design purposely captures the fact that adaptation to a newly enacted right may vary widely across different types of health care organizations as well as engages directly with the unique characteristics inherent in health-care settings. 

The goal of this project is to understand how medical organizations adapt to the imposition of new rights. The study is grounded in sociological theories that emphasize "law on the ground" (that is, what people are actually doing) rather than "law on the books" (formal legal rules) as the primary place to study how law works. Different types of health care organizations in different locations may interpret these regulations differently. Original data will be gathered in the form of 120 in-person interviews in selected areas around the country with the designated grievance handlers in hospitals, doctor's offices, and surgical centers. The study will include both urban and rural health care sites, for example, and private religious hospitals as well as public hospitals. Systematic analysis of interview transcripts will help researchers understand how health care administrators approach problems of rights-enactment in their organizations and whether their solutions vary by type of institution, location, ownership structure, size, and other variables.

por.por_cntn:
This study investigated how complex health care organizations respond to new legal requirements for civil rights and non-discrimination under the Affordable Care Act, Section 1557. This research was important because we know discrimination in health care settings exists, and policy makers thought that discrimination could be a reason why we see large health disparities across groups, such as between white and Black Americans or between transgender people and cisgender people. Outlawing discrimination (and expanding it under the ACA in 2010) could help address health-based inequalities.

The research team reviewed 775 health care settings for website compliance, interviewed health care administrators who were responsible for implementing the regulatory requirements, and analyzed the language of over 1400 health insurance contracts from different market sectors to see what kinds of coverage and exclusions they had. We found wide variation in how hospitals, ambulatory surgical centers, and federally qualified health centers were implementing the non-discrimination requirements, including many who had not even modified their websites as required even a year after regulations were issued and some administrators who had never even heard of the law. Only 290 sites or 37% percent of the 775 organizations included in the web survey had posted the required elements (non-discrimination statement, notice about the grievance process for 1557 specifically, and some contact information for a 1557 grievance officer as a named individual or a generic title), but 63% had not.

But we also found energetic implementation of many features of the law that when beyond what was required, such as hospital committees working to ensure that transgender patients would be called by the right name in every interaction across many types of patient experiences. Unless an organization was complying energetically and dedicating a team of people to untangling all the implications of gender classifications in the delivery of health care, for example, we found that delivering interactional respect became the focus of compliance rather than barriers in delivery of quality care. That is, most patient experience employees focus on how the people who are actually at their facility are treated in the customer service sense and imagine resolving problems through careful communication. They tend not to think of acts such as harassment as legal rights violations that could subject the hospital to a lawsuit, even though the formal law of Section 1557 permits people to sue health care organizations for civil rights violations in court.

 Health insurance plans have mostly removed transition care exclusions, but a significant number remain in the self-insured employer market. Ten companies out of the group of 40 companies whose plans we analyzed from 2019 (25%) offered at least one healthcare contract with a total exclusion on transgender coverage, for example. These contracts represent 38 contracts out of 435 total plans in our research, or just under 9%. The companies vary based on their seeming commitment to their exclusion, with some showing the exclusion in 100% of the contracts we found while others seem to exclude strategically, with only certain contracts--perhaps for some groups of employees or some geographic areas--including an exclusion and others lacking it.

There has been significant legal change around health care discrimination in U.S. law in recent years, particularly the question of whether transgender people are included in sex discrimination laws and whether health insurance must cover gender transition-related costs as a form of non-discrimination and equal treatment. We found that the shifts in what the state of the law actually was did not matter as much as one might think. There were already a lot of reasons why hospital administrators care about making patients happy, and most of those are about avoiding the financial penalties that come from having bad patient satisfaction survey scores, not about avoiding violating patients' civil rights. Whether a health care organization mobilizes around helping a particular group of patients depends on a lot of things like energetic leadership among the doctors, the size of the organization, and its sense of its own mission. Trying to keep patients happy and satisfaction scores high is very different from avoiding violating their legal rights, however, and we found there was very little attention to understanding the issue in these terms. This lack of rights awareness in health care settings could make it difficult to use civil rights laws to reduce health disparities.
